headline.main: PRESIDENT'S LETTER TO CONCORD HIGH SCHOOL

results.snippet: Following is the text of a letter from President Reagan to the faculty and students of Concord High School, where Christa McAuliffe taught:   Today all America joins with you in paying tribute to the memory of a teacher, a friend, a wife and...

byline.original: AP

results.lead_paragraph: Following is the text of a letter from President Reagan to the faculty and students of Concord High School, where Christa McAuliffe taught: Today all America joins with you in paying tribute to the memory of a teacher, a friend, a wife and mother, a leader. The shock and grief, the numbness we all experienced at having Christa McAuliffe so suddenly taken from our midst Tuesday morning is beyond the power of words to express. But through the silence of sorrow we can say that your burden is not only the burden of all Americans, but of people throughout the world who saw in Christa what you who knew her best saw in her - a woman of courage and caring, an educator of boundless energy and inexhaustible enthusiasm, an inspiration to young and old alike.

headline.main: NOBODY SEEMED TO WORRY

results.snippet: Most of us either forgot that flying on rocket power was dangerous or came to believe it wasn't. Either notion, as we now know, was exceedingly foolish.   The disaster of the space shuttle would have been dreadful enough even if we had not...

byline.original: By Russell Baker

results.lead_paragraph: Most of us either forgot that flying on rocket power was dangerous or came to believe it wasn't. Either notion, as we now know, was exceedingly foolish. The disaster of the space shuttle would have been dreadful enough even if we had not forgotten that astronauts work close to the edges of death, but having our foolish delusions about rocketry destroyed in a flash of light turned the event into a national horror. Afterward the first official statements emphasized the Government's determination to pursue the rocketry program despite such events. These statements were inevitable and sensible and made the sensible point that in this kind of work there will always be black days.

headline.main: AT BROOKLYN'S P.S. 5, ASTRONAUT HELD SPECIAL PLACE WITH PUPILS

results.snippet: At P.S. 5, Dr. Ronald E. McNair will always be remembered as a dazzling man in a silver NASA jumpsuit who brought the world of space and rocket ships a little closer to the elementary school children of Brooklyn's inner-city Bedford-Stuyvesant...

byline.original: By SARA RIMER

results.lead_paragraph: At P.S. 5, Dr. Ronald E. McNair will always be remembered as a dazzling man in a silver NASA jumpsuit who brought the world of space and rocket ships a little closer to the elementary school children of Brooklyn's inner-city Bedford-Stuyvesant section. ''That was a grand day,'' Jannie K. Taylor, a first-grade teacher, said yesterday, recalling the astronaut's visit two years ago. ''The children had so many questions. They wanted to know if it rained in space.''

headline.main: INTERIM PANEL PRESSES QUEST FOR CLUES TO EXPLOSION

results.snippet: After a break for the memorial service today, the space agency's interim board of inquiry resumed its quest here for clues to the cause of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.   The six-member board conferred with shuttle specialists at...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: After a break for the memorial service today, the space agency's interim board of inquiry resumed its quest here for clues to the cause of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger. The six-member board conferred with shuttle specialists at the Johnson Space Center all afternoon and prepared to return to the Kennedy Space Center in Florida to continue deliberations through the weekend. A permanent investigation panel organized for a more comprehensive study is expected to be named soon.

headline.main: REAGAN PAYS TRIBUTE TO 'OUR CHALLENGER HEROES'

results.snippet: President Reagan mourned the loss of ''our seven Challenger heroes'' today, paying tribute to their ''brave sacrifice'' and pledging to honor them with a renewed national commitment to the conquest of space.   ''Sometimes when we reach for the...

byline.original: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: President Reagan mourned the loss of ''our seven Challenger heroes'' today, paying tribute to their ''brave sacrifice'' and pledging to honor them with a renewed national commitment to the conquest of space. ''Sometimes when we reach for the stars, we fall short,'' Mr. Reagan said quietly in a solemn outdoor memorial ceremony at the Johnson Space Center before an audience of thousands, including relatives and colleagues of the fallen crew of the space shuttle. ''But we must pick ourselves up again and press on despite the pain.'' As many in the audience dabbed their eyes with handkerchiefs, the President said: ''Man will continue his conquest of space. To reach out for new goals and even greater achievements, that is the way we shall commemorate our seven Challenger heroes.''

headline.main: THE SHUTTLE AND THE ACCIDENT NEXT TIME

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT

results.snippet: To the Editor:   Accidents do happen. Everyone involved with the space program has been aware of it, and every astronaut accepts the risk in the name of discovery.
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Accidents do happen. Everyone involved with the space program has been aware of it, and every astronaut accepts the risk in the name of discovery.

headline.kicker: THE SHUTTLE INQUIRY: NATIONAL MOURNING CONTINUES
headline.main: NEW YORK HONORS THE CHALLENGER'S 7

results.snippet: Seven cannon rounds, one for each of the Challenger astronauts, were fired into the overcast above Central Park yesterday at a memorial service for the victims of the space shuttle explosion. About 500 people, some on skateboards and bicycles,...

byline.original: By CRYSTAL NIX

results.lead_paragraph: Seven cannon rounds, one for each of the Challenger astronauts, were fired into the overcast above Central Park yesterday at a memorial service for the victims of the space shuttle explosion. About 500 people, some on skateboards and bicycles, watched solemnly. Spaced one minute apart, the shots above the park's Belvedere Castle were followed by a brief nonsectarian prayer from Mayor Koch. ''Oh Lord, we pray that you may receive the souls of these your servants,' he said. ''They died in service of their country and in service of all mankind. We shall remember them always.'' After the service, one of many around the country in honor of the seven astronauts, Henry J. Stern, Parks and Recreation Commissioner, told reporters that 122nd Street between Third Avenue and Lexington would be renamed McNair Place, in memory of Dr. Ronald E. McNair, the mission specialist whose father once owned an automobile repair shop there.

headline.main: PRESIDENT NAMES 12-MEMBER PANEL IN SHUTTLE INQUIRY

results.snippet: President Reagan appointed a 12-member independent commission today to take responsibility for investigating the cause of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.   It is time, Mr. Reagan said, to take a ''hard look'' at the disaster that...

byline.original: By GERALD M. BOYD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: President Reagan appointed a 12-member independent commission today to take responsibility for investigating the cause of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger. It is time, Mr. Reagan said, to take a ''hard look'' at the disaster that killed the seven members of the Challenger crew last Tuesday. The panel, the Presidential Commission on the Space Shuttle Challenger Accident, will take over responsiblity for examining the accident, replacing the board already convened by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration as the official investigative body. Report Due in 120 Days William R. Graham, Acting Administrator of the space agency, who attended a White House meeting where Mr. Reagan announced he was creating the panel, said the launching of future shuttles would be suspended until the commission completed its investigation. The group is to report to the President and the NASA Administrator within 120 days.

headline.kicker: THE SHUTTLE INQUIRYMEN IN THE NEWS: NEIL ALDEN ARMSTRONG
headline.main: LEADERS OF INQUIRY INTO THE EXPLOSION

results.snippet: Neil A. Armstrong's appointment yesterday as vice chairman of the President's inquiry into the space shuttle disaster thrust him back into the spotlight 16 years after his walk on the moon. Since that walk he has largely avoided the limelight.  ...

byline.original: By ERIK ECKHOLM

results.lead_paragraph: Neil A. Armstrong's appointment yesterday as vice chairman of the President's inquiry into the space shuttle disaster thrust him back into the spotlight 16 years after his walk on the moon. Since that walk he has largely avoided the limelight. Mr. Armstrong's words as he stepped onto the moon's Sea of Tranquility on July 21, 1969, ''That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind,'' were heard live round the world.

headline.main: REAGAN'S REMARKS ON PANEL

results.snippet: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's statement yesterday on the formation of a commission of inquiry into the Challenger disaster, as recorded by The New York Times:   It's been almost a week since our nation and families stood together...
results.lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's statement yesterday on the formation of a commission of inquiry into the Challenger disaster, as recorded by The New York Times: It's been almost a week since our nation and families stood together as we watched Challenger slip beyond our grasp. The memories of that moment will be with us always, as will the memories of those brave Americans who were aboard. The death of the astronauts and the destruction of the space shuttle Challenger will forever be a reminder of the risks involved with space exploration, and we will always remember the Challenger Seven.

headline.main: RESEARCHERS DRAW BACK THE CURTAIN ON THE MYSTERIOUS AURORA BOREALIS

results.snippet: Ever since human beings first settled this region they have been awed by the aurora borealis - towering, rippling, multicolored curtains of light that often hang above this city on clear, dark nights. Yet only recently have scientists been able to...

byline.original: By WALTER SULLIVAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Ever since human beings first settled this region they have been awed by the aurora borealis - towering, rippling, multicolored curtains of light that often hang above this city on clear, dark nights. Yet only recently have scientists been able to demonstrate the forces that control these ''northern lights.'' In particular the scientists believe they have discovered, through computer simulations and laboratory experiments, the cause of the strikingly uniform folds that often appear in the aurora. Some hope, in addition, to manipulate and ''orchestrate'' aurora displays by beaming powerful radio waves up from the ground. Recent tests have also indicated that a related phenomenon, the polar electrojet, a ''river of electricity'' flowing through the upper atmosphere, may have a practical application. In Norway the electrojet has been used to create extremely low-frequency (ELF) radio waves of the type that the United States Navy would like to use for communication with submerged submarines.

headline.main: 500 ATTEND MASS FOR SPACE TEACHER

results.snippet: About 500 friends, relatives and neighbors of Christa McAuliffe gathered this morning for a funeral mass in a church where she once taught confirmation classes.   The mass was celebrated by the Rev. James Leary, a cousin of the 37-year-old teacher...

byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: About 500 friends, relatives and neighbors of Christa McAuliffe gathered this morning for a funeral mass in a church where she once taught confirmation classes. The mass was celebrated by the Rev. James Leary, a cousin of the 37-year-old teacher who died aboard the space shuttle Challenger. It was Father Leary who married her to Steven McAuliffe in 1970. Mr. McAuliffe, a lawyer, and the couple's two children, Caroline, 6, and Scott, 9, returned home to Concord late Sunday afternoon. The family had traveled to Florida for the launching. Mr. McAuliffe later attended a memorial service in Houston for the seven people who died in the space shuttle explosion.

headline.main: SPACE AGENCY IMAGE: A SUDDEN SHATTERING

results.snippet: Suddenly the image of the space agency has changed.   For years the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has symbolized all that is best in American technology and American technical management.   The Pentagon and its military contractors...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Suddenly the image of the space agency has changed. For years the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has symbolized all that is best in American technology and American technical management. The Pentagon and its military contractors might manufacture costly weapons that did not work. Other industries might produce a frightening nuclear accident at Three Mile Island, a chemical disaster in Bhopal, India, electronics that could not compete with the Japanese or automobiles that needed to be recalled.

headline.main: Nancy Reagan Lends Name To Astronaut Children's Fund

results.snippet: Nancy Reagan has agreed to serve as the honorary head of a trust fund for the children of the astronauts killed in the space shuttle explosion last week, officials of the fund have announced.

byline.original: UPI

results.lead_paragraph: Nancy Reagan has agreed to serve as the honorary head of a trust fund for the children of the astronauts killed in the space shuttle explosion last week, officials of the fund have announced.

headline.kicker: TWO PATHES TO THE STARS: TURNINGS AND TRIUMPHS
headline.main: RONALD MCNAIR

results.snippet: In the harvest season, as a boy and as a young man, Ron McNair sweated his way down the lush green rows of the cotton and tobacco fields that begin just half a mile out of this quiet, back-country town.   It is work of ancient and brutal rhythms, a...

byline.original: By DUDLEY CLENDINEN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: In the harvest season, as a boy and as a young man, Ron McNair sweated his way down the lush green rows of the cotton and tobacco fields that begin just half a mile out of this quiet, back-country town. It is work of ancient and brutal rhythms, a Daguerrotype, almost, of traditional Southern black field labor. Beginning at daybreak, as the dew evaporated in the warming air, the men and women made their way down the rows, bending, plucking, shuffling forward, dragging their sacks, stooping and reaching under the high arc of the sun as the earth grew radiant and the fields shimmered with heat. ''Your back felt like two razor blades meeting,'' Joseph A. Wilson 2d recalls. It took strength. At $4 a day, it took endurance. One had to need the money in order to do that work. But in some cases, it helped make people strong. Here in Lake City, a doctor, a lawyer, an astronaut, a biologist, an entrepreneur and a computer analyst rose from those fields.

headline.main: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: CRUISES FEATURE STARS AND A COMET

results.snippet: There are many criteria for selecting a cruise. Among them are your budget, how long you plan to be away and what part of the world you want to sail in - the Caribbean, Mexico, Alaska, Europe, the Mediterranean or the South Pacific. Other...

byline.original: By PAUL GRIMES

results.lead_paragraph: There are many criteria for selecting a cruise. Among them are your budget, how long you plan to be away and what part of the world you want to sail in - the Caribbean, Mexico, Alaska, Europe, the Mediterranean or the South Pacific. Other considerations are time of year and whether, depending on your preference, the itinerary calls for a preponderance of lazy days at sea or frequent stops at ports. One of the most important factors, however, is what sort of entertainment the cruise offers. The caliber of professional entertainment, or the seriousness with which a cruise pursues a theme (such as classical music, tournament bridge, archeology, financial planning or - this year particularly - astronomy and Halley's Comet), can go far toward determining whether you will enjoy it. The type of entertainment may also indicate what sort of passengers are likely to be on board. ''In the summer, you get a lot of kids, so you book Sha Na Na, that sort of thing,'' said Leo Silverstein, a cruise talent agent in Boca Raton, Fla., in a telephone interview. ''In the winter, the passengers tend to be older, so you give them the Vic Damones, the Petula Clarks, the Jerry Lewises.''

headline.kicker: TWO PATHS TO THE STARS: TURNINGS AND TRIUMPHS
headline.main: JUDITH RESNIK

results.snippet: At Carnegie Mellon University, a plaque in Wean Hall bears the inscription, ''My heart is in the work.'' They are the words of the Pittsburgh school's founder, Andrew Carnegie, but they could be an epitaph for one of the school's most accomplished...

byline.original: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: At Carnegie Mellon University, a plaque in Wean Hall bears the inscription, ''My heart is in the work.'' They are the words of the Pittsburgh school's founder, Andrew Carnegie, but they could be an epitaph for one of the school's most accomplished engineering graduates, Judith A. Resnik. ''Judy was an astronaut's astronaut,'' said Henry Hartsfield, the commander of the 1984 Discovery mission on which she flew. ''She was not satisfied with second best.'' On that first mission, the fledgling astronaut conducted experiments with the shuttlecraft's solar energy instruments. A Complex Personality But Dr. Resnik's reputation for hard work and professionalism did not reflect the full range of her complex personality, according to people who knew her. She captured the imagination not only because she excelled in a competitive profession, but also because she did not seem to match any popular notion of a NASA ''type.'' In the words of a stepsister, ''She wasn't all-American.''

headline.main: STOCKBRIDGE UNEASY OVER ROCKWELL MUSEUM PLAN

results.snippet: Lila Berle stood on a snow-covered slope and pointed out the landmarks in the distance. To the far left was Tanglewood, summer home of the Boston Symphony. Next came Greylock Mountain, whose elongated hump is widely believed to have helped inspire...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Lila Berle stood on a snow-covered slope and pointed out the landmarks in the distance. To the far left was Tanglewood, summer home of the Boston Symphony. Next came Greylock Mountain, whose elongated hump is widely believed to have helped inspire Herman Melville as he wrote ''Moby Dick'' in nearby Pittsfield. Straight ahead was Prospect Hill, on whose crescent stands the former estate of Cyrus Field, who set the first undersea Atlantic cable. ''I was so excited when this became available,'' said Mrs. Berle, the president of the board of directors of the planned Norman Rockwell Museum in this historic New England town. She was referring to the 40-acre estate known as Linwood, which is to be the museum's home.

headline.kicker: 2 SPACE NOVICES WITH A LOVE OF KNOWLEDGE
headline.main: CHRISTA MCAULIFFE

results.snippet: Christa McAuliffe spent her last few days on earth excited and anxious about her space mission, answering mail from well-wishers and telephoning friends as she waited through the delays in the launching of the Challenger.   Eileen O'Hara, a friend...

byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD

results.lead_paragraph: Christa McAuliffe spent her last few days on earth excited and anxious about her space mission, answering mail from well-wishers and telephoning friends as she waited through the delays in the launching of the Challenger. Eileen O'Hara, a friend from Concord, asked how it felt to sit in the orbiter waiting for a liftoff that did not come. ''Go borrow a motorcycle helmet,'' Mrs. McAuliffe reportedly said. ''Lie on the floor, with your legs up on the bed. Lie there for five hours. You can't read, you can't have anything loose around, you're strapped down really tightly, with oxygen lines and wires coming out of your suit. The only people who had anything to do were the pilot and the co-pilot.'' But there was one thing about the delay: it gave her family and friends time to have a nice party at Cape Canaveral and she was glad about that, though she could not attend because of preflight quarantine.

headline.kicker: 3 BOYS' DREAMS OF SPACE, 3 DEATHS IN THE SKY
headline.main: Michael Smith

results.snippet: This part of the country invites flight, with its warm, buoyant air currents and table-flat fields ready-made for landing strips. The wide Atlantic sky is speckled with motion, from the graceful dance of sea birds to the sharp, swift flight of...

byline.original: By THOMAS J. KNUDSON

results.lead_paragraph: This part of the country invites flight, with its warm, buoyant air currents and table-flat fields ready-made for landing strips. The wide Atlantic sky is speckled with motion, from the graceful dance of sea birds to the sharp, swift flight of military aircraft. As a North Carolina farm boy, Mike Smith learned to work the land, but grew to love the sky. He learned to fly as a teen-ager, soaring in a small plane over the sandy spits and pine forests of the Outer Banks, not far from where the Wright Brothers first took to the air. ''Flying is just something that came natural to Mike,'' said his brother Patrick, 39 years old, himself a jet pilot. ''It didn't matter whether it was small airplanes or a jet, he just really loved to fly.''

headline.main: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1986

results.snippet: International The Philippine presidential election was put to the National Assembly for certification after three days of violence and widespread reports of vote-rigging by backers of President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Both President Marcos, whose...
results.lead_paragraph: International The Philippine presidential election was put to the National Assembly for certification after three days of violence and widespread reports of vote-rigging by backers of President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Both President Marcos, whose forces dominate Parliament, and Corazon C. Aquino have claimed victory. [ Page A1, Col. 1. ] The President reserved judgment on reports of fraud in the Philippine election, but said that it had shown the two-party system to be strong. Officials said Mr. Reagan would comment in detail on the situation at his news conference today after conferring with Senator Richard G. Lugar, who headed the American observer team in the election. [ A1:2. ]

headline.kicker: 3 BOYS' DREAMS OF SPACE, 3 DEATHS IN THE SKY
headline.main: Dick Scobee

results.snippet: When Dick Scobee went home to Auburn, Wash., for a family reunion in October, he told people that, with 109 astronauts in the shuttle program, his next flight into space might be his last. An aunt who was present, Naomi Allen, recalls that her...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD

results.lead_paragraph: When Dick Scobee went home to Auburn, Wash., for a family reunion in October, he told people that, with 109 astronauts in the shuttle program, his next flight into space might be his last. An aunt who was present, Naomi Allen, recalls that her nephew, who had never wanted to be anything but an airplane pilot, was nonetheless content. ''He said he had acquired everything he wanted in life,'' she said. Dick Scobee, the little boy who hung so many model airplanes from the ceiling of his room that anyone entering would bump his head on them, died at the command controls of the ultimate airplane, the shuttle Challenger. That he should have risen to such prominence is a source of some marvel to many who knew him when he was young. He was a good but not brilliant student who worked hard. He was a slow football player, but if no one else showed up for practice, Dick Scobee did. Without the privilege of going to the Air Force Academy, he became a pilot and officer the hard way, starting as a enlisted man repairing propeller engines.

headline.main: ...And What They Still Need Help With

results.snippet: To the Editor:   ''Child health experts expressed concern,'' you report (front page, Jan. 30), ''about the psychological impact that the televised death of Christa McAuliffe will have on the nation's schoolchildren.'' This is indeed a legitimate...
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Child health experts expressed concern,'' you report (front page, Jan. 30), ''about the psychological impact that the televised death of Christa McAuliffe will have on the nation's schoolchildren.'' This is indeed a legitimate concern.

headline.main: IN PURSUIT OF THE PERFECT GOLF BALL

results.snippet: WHOOSH. A golf ball rockets off the tee in a perfect trajectory and then plunks down, skitters a bit, and comes to a stop 247 yards away, slightly down the right side of the 9th hole of the Kittansett Country Club in Marion, Mass.   Whoosh. This...

byline.original: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

results.lead_paragraph: WHOOSH. A golf ball rockets off the tee in a perfect trajectory and then plunks down, skitters a bit, and comes to a stop 247 yards away, slightly down the right side of the 9th hole of the Kittansett Country Club in Marion, Mass. Whoosh. This one, bounding down the center of the fairway, expires 266 yards away. Some golfer. Fortunately, you'll never have to meet him in the finals of the club championship. He's a robot. This really isn't the 9th hole at Kittansett. This is inside a theater-like room in New Bedford, Mass., at a laboratory of the Acushnet Company, one of the dominant makers of golf balls. The robot - known as ''Iron Byron,'' since its swing mimicks the classic motion of the stellar professional, Byron Nelson - is firing balls at a net, behind which is a slide projection of Kittansett's 9th hole. Infrared cameras connected to a computer reveal precisely where - and how far -the balls went. The researchers have been studying the aerodynamics of a golf ball, in particular what happens when you change the little circular indentations known as dimples.

headline.main: THE FLASHER OF THE APOCALYPSE

results.snippet: RAT MAN OF PARIS By Paul West. 180 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $15.95.   PAUL WEST'S 10th novel, ''Rat Man of Paris,'' addresses the large question of our time: How does one live one's daily life in the span between past atrocity and...

byline.original: By Lore Segal; Lore Segal's most recent book is a novel, ''Her First American.''

results.lead_paragraph: RAT MAN OF PARIS By Paul West. 180 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $15.95. PAUL WEST'S 10th novel, ''Rat Man of Paris,'' addresses the large question of our time: How does one live one's daily life in the span between past atrocity and atrocity to come? What happens to the wound that does not heal, that will not scar over? Paul West has imagined the mind and times of the historical Rat Man, who used to walk the boulevards of Paris several years ago, opening his coat to flash a live rodent in the faces of strolling Parisians and the tourists in the cafes. He has imagined Rat Man's childhood in an Alsatian village during the Second World War, the inside of Rat Man's room in a derelict Paris street - and he has imagined Rat Man's imagination in the act of producing his several symbolic street performances. The act in which Rat Man carries a picture of ''the Boche'' through the streets of Paris earns him a bullet, fired at him - is it from the right fringe or the left? But at the core of this wonderful book that is about atrocity, Paul West has also allowed Rat Man the goodness of reciprocal love.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS ACTIVE IN QUEST FOR ANSWERS ABOUT DISASTER

results.snippet: The astronauts whose lives depend on the safety of the space shuttle are emerging as active participants in the search for answers to the Challenger explosion. They are expressing their sense of urgency that a safer space program must come out of...
results.lead_paragraph: The astronauts whose lives depend on the safety of the space shuttle are emerging as active participants in the search for answers to the Challenger explosion. They are expressing their sense of urgency that a safer space program must come out of the shuttle disaster. Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy, the astronaut who in 1981 piloted America's first shuttlecraft into space, has become a leading figure in the investigation to find out what led to the explosion of the Challenger Jan. 28. At the Kennedy Space Center, Captain Crippen is officially in charge of operations to find and salvage the Challenger's debris. Unofficially, he is said to determine virtually every aspect of the inquiry here.

headline.main: INQUIRY FOCUSING ON COLD SPOT REPORTS

results.snippet: A member of the Presidential panel investigating the Challenger accident conducted a special investigation here today into reports that abnormally low temperatures were recorded on the launching pad before the space shuttle was launched.   The...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A member of the Presidential panel investigating the Challenger accident conducted a special investigation here today into reports that abnormally low temperatures were recorded on the launching pad before the space shuttle was launched. The presence here of the panel member, Dr. Richard P. Feynman, highlights the growing concern that cold temperatures may have played a major role in the explosion of the Challenger Jan. 28, killing the seven astronauts. Launching pad technicians using an infrared temperature sensing device discovered unusually cold spots on the lower part of the Challenger's right-hand solid-fuel booster rocket shortly before the spacecraft began its fatal flight, sources said today. But the readings, which indicate that the right booster's skin was surprisingly colder than that of the left booster rocket, were not passed along to higher officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration who later made the decision to launch the Challenger, space agency officials testified at a hearing in Washington today.

headline.main: KEY SECTIONS OF NASA TESTIMONY AT SENATE PANEL'S HEARING

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: SENATE SUBCOMMITTEE ON SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND SPACE

results.snippet: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the hearing by the Senate Subcommittee on Science, Technology and Space yesterday in Washington on the loss of the space shuttle Challenger, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC...
results.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the hearing by the Senate Subcommittee on Science, Technology and Space yesterday in Washington on the loss of the space shuttle Challenger, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News: SENATOR ERNEST F. HOLLINGS, Democrat of South Carolina: At this particular juncture it seems like an avoidable accident rather than an unavoidable one. And the only way that we who support the space program are ever going to maintain any credibility in support for it is to make absolutely sure that no accidents like this will ever occur again. I want to make sure that this committee gets every bit of evidence. I've served on Presidential commissions and it's just impossible to get all the situation together. An adversary type proceeding of investigators is necessary to really get us to a conclusive result. WILLIAM P. ROGERS, Chairman of the Commission: The President has asked the commission to take a hard and objective look at the accident, to take a calm, deliberate and independent assessment of the facts, to find out if possible how this accident happened, the causes - the cause or causes -and to recommend ways to avoid a repetition of this tragedy, and finally, to submit a full report within 120 days of the commission's formation on Feb. 3.

headline.main: Quotation of the Day

results.snippet: ''None of us want to go again until we understand what happened and have a fix.'' - Neil A. Armstrong, a former astronaut and the vice chairman of the Presidential commission on the shuttle explosion.  [ B9:2. ]
results.lead_paragraph: ''None of us want to go again until we understand what happened and have a fix.'' - Neil A. Armstrong, a former astronaut and the vice chairman of the Presidential commission on the shuttle explosion. [ B9:2. ]

headline.main: SHUTTLE CHIEF SAYS HE WAS NOT TOLD OF COLD SPOTS ON BOOSTER

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: SENATE SUBCOMMITTEE ON SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND SPACE

results.snippet: Although temperatures as low as 7 to 9 degrees Fahrenheit were recorded in the right-hand booster rocket of the shuttle Challenger on the day it exploded, the head of the space shuttle program said he was not informed about it.   The disclosure was...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Although temperatures as low as 7 to 9 degrees Fahrenheit were recorded in the right-hand booster rocket of the shuttle Challenger on the day it exploded, the head of the space shuttle program said he was not informed about it. The disclosure was made today at an often combative Senate subcommittee hearing at which the official, Jesse W. Moore, testified that he would have asked more probing questions if he had been told about the low temperature readings. However, Dr. William R. Graham, acting director of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, cautioned that the readings were made with optical infrared devices that were ''not easy instruments to operate'' and he warned that measurement errors ''could be quite substantial.'' Mr. Moore, the Associate Administrator for space flight at NASA, told the Senate Commerce subcommittee on space that special ice teams went out on the launching pad at 1:30 A.M., 7 A.M., and 11 A.M. the day of the flight, primarily to determine whether ice on the launching pad or the shuttle's giant fuel tank might break off and damage the shuttle's fragile thermal protection tiles.

headline.main: CHARLES SEES VICTORY SITE, LOSING OUT IN TESTING TACO

results.snippet: The Prince of Wales, on the second day of a four-day visit marking the Republic of Texas's 150th birthday, sampled a taco today and toured an oil refinery and the battlefield where Texas won its independence.   The Prince, riding in a Jaguar sedan,...

byline.original: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Prince of Wales, on the second day of a four-day visit marking the Republic of Texas's 150th birthday, sampled a taco today and toured an oil refinery and the battlefield where Texas won its independence. The Prince, riding in a Jaguar sedan, followed an itinerary that reads like a travelogue. He said he was fascinated by most of what he saw, if taken aback a bit by the Texas heat, which hit a humid 87 degrees as he toured the San Jacinto Monument outside Houston. The monument marks the site of a battle on April 21, 1836, in which Texas forces led by Gen. Sam Houston defeated the Mexican Army of Gen. Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna. The battle secured Texas's independence.

headline.kicker: AS SHUTTLE DETAILS EMERGE, A KEY AIDE SHIFTS JOBS
headline.main: UNEXPECTEDLY QUICK MOVE

results.snippet: Jesse W. Moore, the space agency official who made the final decision to launch the Challenger space shuttle, will leave his position as associate administrator for space flight sooner than expected and be replaced by Richard Truly, a former...

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Jesse W. Moore, the space agency official who made the final decision to launch the Challenger space shuttle, will leave his position as associate administrator for space flight sooner than expected and be replaced by Richard Truly, a former shuttle astronaut, agency sources said last night. Meanwhile, the Presidential commission investigating the Challenger explosion said today that ''at least three key NASA officials'' responsible for the decision to launch the craft had never been informed that engineers working for the manufacturer of the Challenger's booster rockets had ''strongly urged against the launch.'' #3 Officials Not Named The commission declined to name the three officials. One source familiar with the investigation said it would be a ''reasonable assumption'' that the apparent failure by middle-level NASA officials to pass on the warnings prompted the commission to issue its statement over the weekend that the process leading to the decision to launch ''may have been flawed.''

headline.main: EX-ASTRONAUT TO HEAD NASA CHALLENGER INQUIRY

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today appointed a new leader for its investigation into the space shuttle explosion amid signs that the White House and some leaders in Congress were seeking a new administrator to head the troubled...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today appointed a new leader for its investigation into the space shuttle explosion amid signs that the White House and some leaders in Congress were seeking a new administrator to head the troubled agency. The space agency announced that Rear Adm. Richard H. Truly, a former astronaut who currently heads the Naval Space Command, will succeed Jesse W. Moore as associate administrator for space flight. Admiral Truly will also replace Mr. Moore as head the agency's inquiry into the explosion that destroyed the shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, killing all seven astronauts aboard.

headline.main: PANEL EXPLORING ISSUE OF PRESSURE FOR A LAUNCHING

results.snippet: The Presidential commission investigating the space shuttle explosion is increasingly focusing on whether top managers of NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center pressured the manufacturer of the Challenger's booster rockets to approve the launching,...

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Presidential commission investigating the space shuttle explosion is increasingly focusing on whether top managers of NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center pressured the manufacturer of the Challenger's booster rockets to approve the launching, sources close to the panel said today. At a news conference this morning, Jesse W. Moore, the space agency official who gave final approval for the launching, reiterated that he had never been informed of a near-rebellion among the manufacturers' engineers fearful that a launching would lead to disaster. The explosion, 73 seconds into liftoff, killed the seven astronauts on board. New Executive Is Named As expected, Mr. Moore announced he was relinquishing his position as associate administrator in charge of the shuttle project while remaining head of the Johnson Space Center in Houston. Rear. Adm. Richard H. Truly of the Navy is to replace him. [ Page A12. ] Tonight, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration released the document it received from the booster manufacturer the night before the Jan. 28 launching giving final authorization to proceed. Signed by Joseph C. Kilminster, Morton Thiokol Inc.'s vice president for space booster programs, the one-page assessment warned that the O rings sealing critical joints on the booster would harden in the cold and thus take longer to ''seat'' properly, but concludeed with a statement that Morton Thiokol ''recommends STS-51L launch proceed on 28 January 1986.''

headline.main: VETERAN OF SPACE AND ADMINISTRATION: RICHARD HARRISON TRULY

results.snippet: In 1981, when a reporter asked Richard Truly which athletic teams he favored, the astronaut, then orbiting the earth in a space shuttle, answered that he would rather not say because to do so might offend fans of opposing teams.   Now, as director...

byline.original: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

results.lead_paragraph: In 1981, when a reporter asked Richard Truly which athletic teams he favored, the astronaut, then orbiting the earth in a space shuttle, answered that he would rather not say because to do so might offend fans of opposing teams. Now, as director of the shuttle program, Rear Admiral Truly's diplomatic restraint as well as professional prestige will be indispensible to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in its campaign to re-establish public trust after the Challenger disaster. At the age of 48, Admiral Truly, NASA's new associate administrator for space flight, has risen high in two intertwined but separate careers: those of a naval aviator and administrator, and of a NASA astronaut. A consummate pilot, he specialized in difficult night landings, both in carrier-based combat aircraft and in the space shuttle itself. Equally skilled as an administrator, he has served since Oct. 1, 1983, as commander of the Naval Space Command, an agency responsible for all the Navy's surveillance and communications satellites.

headline.main: SPACE AGENCY MAINTAINS SILENCE ON ANY REMAINS OF SHUTTLE CREW

results.snippet: Shortly after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, a team of military pathologists and forensic experts was flown here to help in the identification of any human remains that might be recovered, the space agency said today.   But the...

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Shortly after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, a team of military pathologists and forensic experts was flown here to help in the identification of any human remains that might be recovered, the space agency said today. But the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said the experts from the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology flew back to Washington after spending several days here preparing for the investigation. ''If we have need of their services, I will call them and they will respond,'' said Capt. Joseph P. Kerwin of the Navy, a former astronaut who is director of Space and Life Sciences at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. More than three weeks after the shuttle was destroyed in a fireball above the Atlantic Ocean, killing all seven crew members, it is still unclear what, if any, human remains have been recovered as a result of an extensive sea search off the Florida coast.

headline.main: Shuttle Investigators Wonder Why Engineer's Warnings Went Unheeded

results.snippet: What did NASA officials know, when did they know it and why did they not do more about it? Those questions were raised by a disquieting series of revelations last week concerning the launching of the ill-fated space shuttle Challenger.   As a...
results.lead_paragraph: What did NASA officials know, when did they know it and why did they not do more about it? Those questions were raised by a disquieting series of revelations last week concerning the launching of the ill-fated space shuttle Challenger. As a Presidential panel pieced together the events that led to America's worst space tragedy, NASA documents showed that agency officials had during the last few years repeatedly discussed potential problems with the O rings, the seals in the shuttle's solid fuel booster rockets that are supposed to prevent explosive gas from leaking. The rings are prime suspects in the blast that killed all seven Challenger crew members Jan. 28. But yesterday, a former official of Morton Thiokol Inc., the company that built the boosters, said he thought the explosion may have been caused by a leak in the shuttle's huge external fuel tank.

headline.main: ROCKET EXPERT BACKS ALTERNATE THEORY

results.snippet: A retired executive of Morton Thiokol Inc., the company that builds the booster rockets for the space shuttle, said today he believed that a hydrogen leak from the huge external fuel tank, not a booster failure, was the most likely cause of the...

byline.original: By ROBERT LINDSEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A retired executive of Morton Thiokol Inc., the company that builds the booster rockets for the space shuttle, said today he believed that a hydrogen leak from the huge external fuel tank, not a booster failure, was the most likely cause of the Challenger explosion that killed seven astronauts Jan. 28. A leak of supercold hydrogen gas from the external tank had initially been a major focus of theories on the disaster's cause. But attention shifted to the booster rockets after photographs showed a plume of flame coming from the right-side booster and after a loss in thrust in the booster after liftoff was reported. Earlier this week Neil A. Armstrong, the former astronaut who is vice chairman of the Presidential commission investigating the shuttle explosion, said a leak of supercold gas from the tank was ''one of a number of scenarios'' still being examined.

headline.main: BORMAN'S TENURE SEEN NEAR AN END

results.snippet: Eastern Air Lines Inc.'s decision yesterday to sell itself to the Texas Air Corporation appears to end Frank Borman's rocky 10-year tenure at the helm of the troubled airline.   An official of the International Association of Machinists union and...

byline.original: By STEVEN PROKESCH

results.lead_paragraph: Eastern Air Lines Inc.'s decision yesterday to sell itself to the Texas Air Corporation appears to end Frank Borman's rocky 10-year tenure at the helm of the troubled airline. An official of the International Association of Machinists union and two Eastern outside directors said that the former astronaut planned to resign from the company. Speculation intensified that Mr. Borman, who headed the Gemini 7 and Apollo 8 missions, might become the administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Mr. Borman, who joined Eastern as senior vice president for operations in 1970 and became chief executive in 1975, could not be reached for comment yesterday. But Jerry Cosley, Eastern's senior vice president for corporate communications, quoted Mr. Borman, 58 years old, as saying ''as far as I know I wasn't offered a job'' at Texas Air.

headline.main: MANY TROUBLESOME YEARS

results.snippet: The decision by Eastern Airlines to accept a takeover offer by the Texas Air Corporation was preceded by many troublesome years for the company. These are among some of the important developments that led to the decision:   December 1975: Frank...
results.lead_paragraph: The decision by Eastern Airlines to accept a takeover offer by the Texas Air Corporation was preceded by many troublesome years for the company. These are among some of the important developments that led to the decision: December 1975: Frank Borman, a former astronaut who joined Eastern in 1970 as a senior vice president, takes over as chief executive officer of the airline, which is already experiencing financial difficulties. Mid-1970's: With fuel prices rising, Eastern's fleet is modernized, and heavy debt is incurred to buy new Airbuses and Boeing 757's. The airline has the most fuel-efficient planes in the sky, but fuel prices eventually drop.

headline.main: SHUTTLE CRASH: WHERE CLUES HAVE LED SO FAR

results.snippet: JUST four weeks after history's worst space disaster, much is already known about the events and circumstances preceding the space shuttle Challenger's explosive end. Suspect components, cold weather and some apparent lapses in human judgment all...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

results.lead_paragraph: JUST four weeks after history's worst space disaster, much is already known about the events and circumstances preceding the space shuttle Challenger's explosive end. Suspect components, cold weather and some apparent lapses in human judgment all seem to be implicated. The pieces of the puzzle, when fitted together, begin to tell of the roles of key engineers and managers in critical shuttle decisions, the knowledge available to them and withheld from them and the pressures under which they worked and made the decision to launch the Challenger on its last mission - a mission that would bring the American space enterprise to an indefinite halt. With public hearings into the disaster set to resume today, a cascade of new disclosures is likely to expose other flaws in shuttle systems and in the decision-making process leading up to the launching on Jan. 28 that killed all seven aboard the Challenger. More questions will undoubtedly be raised about malfunctions in the right booster rocket. New evidence will be presented about serious safety concerns that, for reasons that are still mysterious, were not called to the attention of top space agency managers.

headline.main: BEGGS RESIGNS AS HEAD OF NASA

results.snippet: James M. Beggs, under indictment on fraud charges, resigned today as Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Mr. Beggs, who has been on leave from his post, took the action to let President Reagan name a new chief for...

byline.original: AP

results.lead_paragraph: James M. Beggs, under indictment on fraud charges, resigned today as Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Mr. Beggs, who has been on leave from his post, took the action to let President Reagan name a new chief for the beleaguered space agency. Albert R. Brashear, a White House spokesman, said that Mr. Beggs's letter of resignation was received this afternoon and that Mr. Reagan would move quickly to name a successor.

headline.main: BORMAN PLANS TO STAY FOR NOW

results.snippet: Frank Borman, the chairman and chief executive of Eastern Airlines, said today that he would continue to head the company at least until the carrier's acquisition by the Texas Air Corporation was formally approved.   At a news conference here held...

byline.original: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Frank Borman, the chairman and chief executive of Eastern Airlines, said today that he would continue to head the company at least until the carrier's acquisition by the Texas Air Corporation was formally approved. At a news conference here held jointly with Frank Lorenzo, Texas Air's chairman, Mr. Borman, who has led Eastern for 10 years, declined to be more specific about his plans. Asked how long he would stay on at Eastern, which agreed Monday to be acquired by Texas Air, Mr. Borman said, ''Who knows?'' Mr. Lorenzo said he would honor Mr. Borman's contract, which Mr. Borman said was a ''very long'' one.

headline.main: A DIFFERENT NASA: AGENCY ATTITUDES HAD SHIFTED

results.snippet: In a day of frequently conflicting, sometimes emotional testimony, the key players in the launching of the space shuttle Challenger managed to agree on one point:   The atmosphere of decision-making at the space agency mysteriously changed the day...

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: In a day of frequently conflicting, sometimes emotional testimony, the key players in the launching of the space shuttle Challenger managed to agree on one point: The atmosphere of decision-making at the space agency mysteriously changed the day before the craft's fatal explosion, making the launching of flight 51-L different from any previous shuttle mission. No one, least of all the clearly agitated members of the Presidential panel investigating the disaster, seemed able to explain the cause of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's apparent insistence that the liftoff proceed on Jan. 28. But for the first time, the session today suggested a significant change of attitude within the space agency - a new attitude that may have dismissed or ignored warnings last August by engineers for the builder of the shuttle's booster rockets that disaster was in the offing, an attitude that, the night before launching, subtly created pressure to keep quiet and keep on schedule. In the past, the engineers for Morton Thiokol Inc. testified, they were forced to defend every assertion that their equipment was ready for a safe launching. But this time, ''I had the feeling we were in the position of proving it was unsafe, instead of the other way around,'' said Brian Russell, one of several who strongly urged the company to block a launching, only to be reversed by upper-level managers.

headline.main: No 'Star Wars' Lesson In Challenger Disaster

results.snippet: To the Editor:   '' 'Star Wars' - as 'Perfect' as Challenger?'' by Adele Simmons and John Sanbonmatsu (Op-Ed, Feb. 9) is a typical example of recent arguments about technology that seize upon a dramatic incident as a symbol for argumentation, but...
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: '' 'Star Wars' - as 'Perfect' as Challenger?'' by Adele Simmons and John Sanbonmatsu (Op-Ed, Feb. 9) is a typical example of recent arguments about technology that seize upon a dramatic incident as a symbol for argumentation, but do not make any logical connection. The Challenger space-shuttle tragedy reminded us that being an astronaut is a hazardous job. It should suggest that we owe a debt to those who have the courage to accept the risks in carrying out our space-exploration program. Being launched into space is a dangerous enterprise for those who are sitting atop the large rocket system.

headline.main: ROCKWELL CLOSELY TIED TO THE SHUTTLE PROGRAM

results.snippet: The Rockwell International Corporation, whose officials testified today about their expressions of concern before the launching of the space shuttle Challenger, has been more intimately involved in the shuttle program than any other contractor.  ...

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Rockwell International Corporation, whose officials testified today about their expressions of concern before the launching of the space shuttle Challenger, has been more intimately involved in the shuttle program than any other contractor. Its principal function for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is building spacecraft, although it performs other important tasks for the agency. It assists in flight planning, astronaut training and other support work, and it has led a project to build individual components that could be assembled form a new spacecraft.
